content.description: Climb the left side of a white streak to crescent shaped layback. Keep moving to just below a bulge. Muscle the bulge to ring anchors.

climbs.name: Under the Eye of the Vulture

content.description: A sequential, bouldery start leads to a rest. Fun and interesting moves through the middle, to a puzzling bulge below the anchors. Originally a mixed route with two less bolts.
content.location: The last route in the Quiet Zone. At the far west end of permissibly accessed land.

content.description: 3 bolts to chain anchors
content.location: Goes over a obvious 3 foot overhang

content.description: Fun technical climbing up a shallow corner to a small roof. Easy after the roof.
content.location: between (too good to be true and brickyard). has name plate

content.description: Starts in front of oak tree.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chain anchors. First bolt is angle head
content.location: Starts in front of oak tree.

content.description:
The Dixie Cragger's Atlas calls this a "mixed" route. I guess for King's Bluff it is a little run out... maybe ten or twelve feet if I remember correctly. 

  It's long for King's - a fun climb.
content.protection: You don't need any gear. It's got 5 bolts. There aren't any "no-fall" zones.
content.location: It starts at a basketball-sized hole at your knees. Undercling a smaller hole above your head and step up to start.

content.description: Wide, shallow dihedral right of rotten flake

climbs.name: Shitbox
climbs.fa: Scott Griggs / Eric Boarman / Doyle Parsons / Todd Thomas

content.description: This route may clean up, eventually... but for now, don't expect great rock quality. Hell, Todd cleaned so much rock off the upper half on his ascent, Im not even sure there's any rock at all left up there! Its probably a new route now and needs to be renamed and regraded. Anyway, if you do decide to do this death trap, I mean future classic, be careful what you pull on. And for Pete's sake, please wear a helmet (especially while belaying), and dont let anyone hang out under it while you're climbing!!! Ok, disclaimer aside, the roof pull on this thing is actually fun! And it is tall for the area. If nothing else, get on it for the experience! Maybe we'll make "I survived Shitbox" stickers someday...
Mixed climb
nearly straight up 40 feet
Climbs slightly left 40 ft
Really good route that starts left of Stone Dagger on some tufa features that soon end to a crux with thin crimps and some harder moves to the roof. Pull the roof and enjoy jugs to the anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chain anchors. Consider stick clipping the first bolt.

content.description: Mixed climbing. Through a white dihedral
Starts 5 feet left of two stacked boulders
Mellow climbing to first bolt. Then, an interesting harder section, which eases up before a reachy anchor clip. Beware of hollow rock above anchor!
content.location: Left of A Break From The Heat

content.description: 3rd route on the right
Fun King's Bluff route.  The first clip is a little runout (consider stick clip, but definately not necessary).
content.protection: No pro needed.  Three bolts to chain anchors.
content.location: Thanks to the name plates, it couldn't be easier to find!  Fourth route on the entire bluff.  Walk down the stairs turn right and walk till you don't see bolted routes anymore, and that will be the Quiet Zone.

content.description: Follows a shallow dihedral

climbs.name: Da Bulge
climbs.fa: Eric Boarman / Bobby Melvin / Matthew Sonneby / Scott Griggs

content.description: Boulder through a stiff start, up a blocky bulge, to a mantle move at a ledge. From there, find the cryptic crimps that will get you to the chains. Sandstone-esque rock sections and movement.
content.location: Right of Injun-eering. Left of Snoopin'.

content.description: Starts on a small boulder. High first bolt, consider stick clipping. Easy climbing to first bolt. Hardest part was around 2nd and 3rd anchors. After that follow the bolts for thin handholds and solid feet to the chains.
content.location: In the middle of Quiet Zone, climber's right of the tree. Name plate as of April 2015.

content.description: Route stays right of blocky corner
Sport Climbing
content.protection: Four Bolts to Chain Anchors. The original bolt for the mixed climb is also there, but clipping it is not advised.
content.location: Climb the right side of a 15' flake that starts 15' off the ground, then over a 3' roof

content.description:
Start with some moderate crimps, aiming for the obvious crack. Jam the crack and follow it up. Continue up until, holds are good the entire way. Route gets a little run out in between the 3rd and 4th hold, but it's fairly easy climbing so nothing to worry about. 

  The Dixie Cragger's Atlas still has this listed as a mixed route, however it looks like someone added two more bolts and it is now one of the best moderate sport climbs at King's Bluff.
content.location: Look for the plaque. Route is near the end of the Quiet Zone before you enter the Forbidden Zone.

climbs.name: [Redacted]
climbs.fa: JB Bell / Eric Boarman / Rob Huffman

content.description: Put up by an "injun" and an engineer, this route confronts you with puzzle after puzzle. Don't be surprised by a few try-really-hard-for-the-grade moves, as you can find just enough rest between each to keep it together. Rock quality is much better than it looks from the ground. Stick clip recommended, if not solid at the grade here!
content.location: Right of Easy For Now, left of Da Bulge.

content.description: The harder routes here usually mean that this section of the wall lives up to its name.
